sn22.88:1.2: Not to be confused with the shameless Assaji of MN 70:4.1, this is probably the early disciple of that name (MN 35:3.1). Assaji was one the group of five mendicants who received the Buddha’s first discourse (Kd 1:6.36.1). Shortly afterwards he inspired Sāriputta with a classic epitome of the teaching (Kd 1:23.2.1).
sn22.88:3.10: This is possibly in reference to Godhika, who likewise was distressed by his inability to keep up his meditation (SN 4.23:1.4). States of samādhi are conditioned and dependent on a healthy body, which is why the Bodhisatta needed to eat before he became enlightened (MN 36:33.2). The Buddha urges final Nibbana, which is not a state of consciousness, but freedom from attachment.
sn22.88:3.11: The notion that even an arahant can decline is discussed and rejected at Kv 1.2.
